image.altText: A woman with long brown hair sits on a wood bench

props.synopsis: In a personal video message, the princess described the news as a "huge shock" and asked for "time, space and privacy" while she undergoes preventative chemotherapy.

title.children: Princess Kate reveals cancer diagnosis after intense speculation about health

image.altText: Alexander Maconochie Centre is Canberra's only prison.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for Rebecca Krutsky, who threw boiling tea on a Narcotics Anonymous volunteer at Canberra's jail scalding her chest, neck and back, say she is now a changed woman and wants to apologise to the victim.

title.children: 'Just two cuppas': Canberra prisoner faces court for throwing boiling tea at Narcotics Anonymous volunteer

image.altText: The sign out of the front of the building and the crest, with an autumnal tree nearby and a blue sky beyond.

props.synopsis: Canberra man Rabea Fares is behind bars after he and his wife Lina Faris staged a car accident so they could make fraudulent insurance claims, in a case the judge said was driven by greed rather than need.

title.children: Canberra couple sentenced for staging car crash to commit insurance fraud

image.altText: bull ants in test tubes bred in Canberra

props.synopsis: They're on the footpath, ruining your picnic and marching through the pantry, but selling ants is big business, as one enthusiast harvesting, collecting and breeding bull ants, black ants and sugar ants to export around the world has discovered.

title.children: How much would you pay for a bull ant?

image.altText: Image of a member of the Russian National Guard in army attire with a large automatic weapon. His face is covered.

props.synopsis: Gunmen burst into a large concert hall on the edge of Moscow, spraying visitors with automatic gunfire and starting a massive blaze.

title.children: Moscow concert hall attack leaves dozens dead and more than 100 injured, according to Russian authorities

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: A man convicted of one of Canberra's most brutal murders has one year added to his original jail term for the killing after committing a separate aggravated robbery, breaching his good behaviour order.

title.children: Canberra convicted killer sentenced to more jail time after breaching good behaviour order

image.altText: Two Australian fighter jets fly during sunset

props.synopsis: British Defence Secretary Grant Shapps picked a novel way to travel to high-level ministerial talks in Adelaide on Thursday, hitching a ride in a RAAF fighter jet for the short commute from Canberra.

title.children: British defence secretary hitches ride to Adelaide on RAAF fighter jet

image.altText: People crowded around and liked up at check-in terminals at Rex Airlines departures area at Sydney Airport

props.synopsis: With Grand Prix events kicking off in Melbourne this week, prices for last seats on planes soared above $900. Experts say raising prices during high-demand periods has been excessive since COVID and they expect to see more of it over Easter.

title.children: 'How far can the airline go?' High demand leads to soaring domestic flight prices

image.altText: Britain's Kate, the Princess of Wales.

props.synopsis: In a video shot in Windsor, Catherine, Princess of Wales, announces her cancer diagnosis. Here is the transcript.

title.children: Princess Kate has announced a cancer diagnosis. Here is her statement in full

image.altText: Three men vote at a polling station in Hobart, Tasmania.

props.synopsis: Most of the more than 400,000 enrolled Tasmanians will cast their votes today, deciding which, if any, major political party can form majority government.

title.children: Tasmania votes: Here's what you need to know for the 2024 state election

image.altText: An aerial view of houses in Hobart, Tasmania.

props.synopsis: Visit Tasmania and you'll get a sense that the cost of living — and affordable access to housing — will be at the forefront of voters' thoughts as the pencil marks down the numbers that will decide the next government.

title.children: Australia has an immense housing problem. Does Tasmania's election offer any solutions for all of us?

image.altText: Anthony Albanese, Mark Dreyfus Labor party room _O6A8332

props.synopsis: There is confusion over just who has seen the federal government's plans for a religious discrimination act, despite the prime minister insisting his cabinet colleagues had viewed two pieces of draft legislation.

title.children: Senior members of the government cast doubt on PM's cabinet assertion

image.altText: A poster of two men joined at the abdoment which says The Wonderful World Renowned Siamese Twins Chang-Eng

props.synopsis: At the height of their fame, conjoined twins Chang and Eng Bunker had meetings with politicians and royalty, popularising the term "Siamese twins".

title.children: Conjoined twins Chang Eng were labelled a 'bad omen' at birth. They left behind a legacy stretching across the centuries

image.altText: A middle aged politician pointing

props.synopsis: An unofficial NDIS event held by a private company in the Great Hall at Parliament House, which cost hundreds of dollars to attend, has been referred to the consumer watchdog after wrongly promoting that government ministers would be in attendance.

title.children: Bill Shorten refers conference to consumer watchdog for falsely promoting him as keynote speaker

image.altText: Young people partying

props.synopsis: It has long been considered a cheesy holiday for the elderly or families. But now, cruises have started to appeal to an unlikely cohort: people in their 20s.

title.children: The surprise group of people driving a resurgence of the cruise industry

image.altText: A house with a pool and dim lights pictured at night.

props.synopsis: Two Australians claim they were victims of a villa investment scam in Bali after transferring more than $120,000 for a villa "that didn't exist", while people from the other side of the world were allegedly conned by a different ruse run by the same alleged con woman, who the ABC understands has just returned to NSW.

title.children: This Bali villa investment seemed too good to be true, and it cost these Aussies a lot to find out

props.synopsis: The inventor of karaoke dies and self-stabbing rituals across Bali — this week in the Asia Pacific in photos.

title.children: The inventor of karaoke dies and self-stabbing rituals across Bali — the Asia Pacific this week in photos

image.altText: A Crows players stands and watches a fan fall to ground as a security officer runs over in the middle of the game.

props.synopsis: Chris Scott and Matthew Nicks raise concerns about the safety of players after the Crows' Ben Keays helped bring to ground a spectator who ran onto Adelaide Oval during the Cats' 19-point win.

title.children: AFL coaches slam 'dangerous' Adelaide Oval pitch invader amid player safety concerns

image.altText: Tesla and SpaceX's CEO Elon Musk gestures at an event.

props.synopsis: Seeking medical advice about treatment for depression is wiser than taking Elon Musk's advice on which drugs to use, writes Julaine Allan.

title.children: Elon Musk says ketamine can get you out of a 'negative frame of mind'. What does the research say?

image.altText: People attend a job fair for university graduates at a gymnasium

props.synopsis: Jobs in China's "iron rice bowl" once offered financial security and stability for life. But now, Beijing has to address the unusual challenges that come with too many young people vying for public service jobs.

title.children: It used to be the 'iron bowl' for upwardly mobile Chinese kids. Could it ruin the rising superpower's economy?

image.altText: Girl at computer with emojis and speech bubble reading 'Are you alone?'

props.synopsis: Young people are being targeted by criminals online, but parents, carers and friends have the power to protect their loved ones.

title.children: 'Sextortion' and exploitation online are rife, but there are ways to protect young people from predators

image.altText: Graham Quirk (AAP) and John Coates (ABC) head shots in front of an Olympic ring logo and stadium lights.

props.synopsis: Monday's dramatic about-face by Premier Steven Miles was arguably the inevitable result of two totally different visions for the Games that have been on a collision course for about a decade.

title.children: Brisbane's Olympic venue dispute the inevitable result of two dramatically different visions

image.altText: Max Verstappen in his Red BUll F1 car driving on track at Albert Park in Melbourne past a grandstand

props.synopsis: Australian Grand Prix organisers say this year's event will attract a record-breaking crowd. But is the benefit as it seems?

title.children: The Australian Grand Prix is expecting a record turnout — but how much does it benefit Victorians?

image.altText: A woman leaps through the air toward a sandpit competing in long jump in front of a grandstand

props.synopsis: The future of the 2026 Commonwealth Games is again uncertain after Malaysia rejected an offer to host the event, citing costs and an insufficient funding offer.

title.children: 2026 Commonwealth Games in doubt after Malaysia rejects offer to host the event

image.altText: Three Rabbitohs NRL players look dejected during loss to Sydney Roosters.

props.synopsis: Conceding eight tries in a humiliating 48-6 loss to the Sydney Roosters continues the Rabbitohs' winless start to the NRL season, with Jason Demetriou admitting the result "hurts".

title.children: 'Lowest point in my career': Rabbitohs coach Demetriou searching for answers after Roosters thrashing

image.altText: People sit behind a desk with their hands raised in a vote

props.synopsis: The UN Security Council fails to pass a resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza on the same day Israel's Prime Minister vowed to send troops into Rafah without US support if necessary.

title.children: Russia and China vote against ceasefire in Gaza in latest UN Security Council resolution

image.altText: A TV still of Annette Bening on a tennis court. She's smiling, and holding her racket up.

props.synopsis: The latest adaptation of a Liane Moriarty novel — after Big Little Lies and Nine Perfect Strangers — follows the Delaney family after the matriarch, Joy, disappears.

title.children: Tennis clubs and missing persons: The latest WASP whodunnit from Liane Moriarty hits TV

image.altText: An older woman with a green jumper standing outside a real estate office looking wistfully

props.synopsis: It is estimated that 90 per cent of advertised rental listings in the popular NSW tourist area and mountain region west of Sydney are short-term accommodation.

title.children: Rental shortage in Blue Mountains has left people like Julie with 'nowhere to go'. Angry locals blame Airbnb

image.altText: Historic portraits of two young men. One has short hair and a beard, while the other is clean-shaven.

props.synopsis: The graves of Captain Moonlite and James Nesbitt are being considered for the state heritage register, not only for their notoriety as colonial-era criminals, but for their publicly acknowledged same-sex relationship.

title.children: Final resting place of queer bushranger pair in line for heritage recognition

image.altText: William Tyrrell's foster mother in a black jumper and white shirt underneath, walking with her husband outside court

props.synopsis: The foster father was cleared of allegations that the child was assaulted, while the foster mother was also found to have intimidated the child on two occasions.

title.children: Former foster parents of William Tyrrell found guilty of intimidation of different child

image.altText: A quiet street in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

props.synopsis: Property analysis firm CoreLogic says that despite extraordinary property market price gains in recent years, demand remains robust.

title.children: 'I don't think it's a Ponzi scheme,' leading economist says, as Australia's median property value rises by $63,000 in a year

image.altText: A young smiling woman embraces a young man, whose back is to the camera. Another smiling woman is visible in the background.

props.synopsis: Hosting is second nature to some and sweat-inducing for others, but etiquette experts Julie Lamberg-Burnet and Amanda King have tips to help guide you through the Easter long weekend.

title.children: Advice for the uneasy host (or house guest) this Easter

image.altText: A group of people stand in the valley floor surrounded by mountains

props.synopsis: It was supposed to be an adventurous day-trip deep into New Zealand's rugged Southern Alps, but on February 12, 1962, the tourists on board the Dragonfly never came home.

title.children: This rugged coastline is the site of mysterious crashes. One expert calls it 'New Zealand's Bermuda Triangle'
